reviews.review: A true masterpiece to this very day; Half-Life is worth every cent.The modding support is great (especially with Sven Co-Op), the story is great and the gameplay is outstanding! This game (and it's sequel!) gives every CoD game a 200 kilometer-per-hour kick in the testicles despite being made earlier than said game. And by the way, don't buy the Source version of this game (it's a really glitchy mess of a port with little to no modding support).

So I got this game to see if it would hold up to a modern set of thinking, and short of the final level I think this holds up well. The controls are still tight for a game from 1999, but some puzzles might throw you for a loop and make you say "Can I Kill some more soldiers and aliens now please?"

What's the first thing that comes to mind, when reviewing a video game? Well, for me, it has to be the visual world that captures the core of our imaginations. And with this little gem called Half-Life, it's no exception that this game continues to boggle the mind and leave people wondering. There is more heart, creativity and scientific ingenuity there is in this one title than there is in most series and is arguably Valve's greatest achievement. (With over 50 game awards, it's a strong justification). Half-Life isn't just one of the greatest FPS games of all time. It's not because Half-Life is one of the best purchases you can ever get on Steam. Half-Life is quite simply, one of the greatest games ever made.

When compared to certain FPS games in the past and modern times, which both heavily rely on long-winded cutscenes to glorify the main plotline, Half-Life annihilates this compulsed aspect, by detailing the plotlines that keeps the player still in control of the first-person viewpoint, leaving the cutscenes rolling while you still have full access to the gameplay and character controllability. For clarification, You will see through the eyes of Gordon Freeman at all times.

The game is a constant puzzle; leaving the player to work at tasks that involve being locked into battle and overall puzzle solving to advance through the many challenges that wait up ahead. Most of the time, the story illuminates the puzzles by the actions to proceed, such as maze scenarios and building boxes to use as staircases. Though Half-Life has short-lived loading screens from time to time after leaving a certain area for a new one, the game has no levels. But, to make up for this traditional concept, the game is split into a number of mind-boggling chapters filled with rich story glory.

To start off with this game's story, you're none other than Gordon Freeman. A young man who holds a Ph.D in theoretical physics who starts his daily grind back at the Black Mesa Research Facility; a fictional complex that is stranded in a remote desert located in the suburbs of New Mexico. Arriving late for work yet again, you take the tram system around the Black Mesa Research Facility and at this point, objectives that his game has fulfilled such as breath-taking visuals and movie quality animation begins to blossom. The tram sequence at the beginning of the game can only be summed up in one word; Incredible. It's as if the things that come flying at you from every angle and position, almost reminiscent of watching an action-packed movie, along with the credits of the producer's names proudly fading in and out on the corner of the screen.

As you make your first step in the heavily secured facility, you're constantly reminded that you put on your Hazardous Enviromental suit, or the H.E.V suit for short. While all things are hunky-dory, those things soon turn to the worst very soon. After a failed experiment, involving a collision between a rare intergalactic specimen from another dimension with an Anti-Mass Spectrometer, the Black Mesa facility falls in ruins, meaning you are one of the only key survivors of the infamous ''Black Mesa Incident''. And with this, alien life-forms from the dimension of ''Xen'' are pulled from their dimension into ours and are running amok the ruined facility, along with the Army that storm the place after the gone, haywired facility's emergency call has been echoed. This of course doesn't make things any easier and you soon find yourself battling both the aliens and army.

While there isn't exactly much to complain about, I would admit that guiding the chickened-out scientists and professors around the facility can be quite a pain now and again, as well as the alien life-form, Vortigaunt, from which you would have to wait and be patient for them to wreck down wooden doors in front of you, as you are not capable of doing that yourself. (You do start off with a crowbar, right?) As well as I'm probably not the only one who made the same mistake by killing them through a small opening, before they did in fact begin to tear down the doors. But then again, this is where the used scripted intermissions started to show, so that's an added bonus.

For the long run, I've had fun and joy both reviewing this amazing game and playing this amazing game. If you haven't play Half-Life and you're not familiar with Half-Life, it's still a massive recommendation from me.

Another one of my favs. I highly recommend at least one playthrough for anyone interested in experiencing game making history. No other game made me dream about it as vividly as this one. I still remember the first time I entered Black Mesa, and I can't stop coming back.

After Quake's 1996 debut, multiple trends of 3D First Person design came about, one of which was Valve's Half-Life in 1998. In opposition to other FPSs that focused on a more heavily arcade-influenced gameplay (secrets, par times, quick action), Half-Life was almost entirely designed around a linear first-person narrative structure, watching the events unfold around them through the eyes of Gordon Freeman. 

Half-Life's blend of story and gameplay is what sells the game. You participate in this fast-paced horror/science-fiction/action journey through an enormous scientific complex and it feels incredibly satisfying to do so. Watching the enviorment go through various shades of Underground Laboratory Bunker gives you a real sense of scale at how Black Mesa is. 

The weapons are a huge component of the game's atmosphere, with different areas giving you different weapons, all of them fun to use in some way. The game takes full advantage of its weapon selection not just from a story perspective but a character perspective as well. Gordon is a young, relatively inexperienced researcher who fights against the expected norms in this scenario by repeatedly fighting his way through Black Mesa backpacking all manner of experimental and unconventional weaponry. Learning how to use all of them makes a playthrough so much more satisfying than if you were to just sprint through with just the first four guns you grab.

The first Half-Life stands well apart from other expansions, mods, and even its own sequel. Opposing Force and Blue Shift, while satisfactory expansions don't maintain the uniquely original aura of the first game. Black Mesa, despite touting itself as a remake, really only succeeds in presenting a more modern and realistic setting. The rest of the mod is just poorly-playtested gunk. It's just not as fun to play as the original game. Ditching Xen to chase the multiplayer carrot didn't help either. Half-Life 2 just isn't as interesting a game as the first one. It manages to simultaneosly have worse gameplay, story, and artstyle than the first game.

[h1]NOTE 2:[/h1]
I review games to help fellow gamers decide whether they should purchase a game or not.  With that said, although I consider Half-Life as a classical MASTERPIECE and possibly one of the greatest games of all time, I will still list down game mechanics from the past that some people may not enjoy today.

Think of it like this: everyone enjoys flying modern-day commercial jets like the 747, but it doesn't mean however that everyone would like to fly in a DC-3 built in the 1940s despite it being labeled as the 'most significant transport aircraft' in history.

[h1]INTRODUCTION:[/h1]
Half-Life is a narrative-driven linear first-person shooter (FPS) action game and is the debut (and signature) title of Valve.  Hailed as one of the greatest games of all time winning dozens of awards on release, Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre in a way that no other title has done since Wolfenstein 3D, Doom and Quake. This game has since been the industry standard on how to make a perfect FPS game which combines realistic gameplay, fun puzzles mechanics, a narrative-driven single-player experience with fast-paced multiplayer action.

The game follows the story of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist working for the Black Mesa Research Facility that is involved in Weapons Development, Research on Teleportation Technology and occasional cloning of a Security Guard named Barney Calhoun.  When an experiment with an unknown alien crystal results in a catastrophic accident that opened a portal to an alien dimension named 'Xen', Gordon Freeman, wearing the H.E.V. Suit, must now travel across the entire Black Mesa facility to reach the Lambda Complex where he must enter a portal to Xen and kill the creature that is keeping the portal open for the alien invaders. Fight against Invading alien monsters and, at the same time, US Military operatives who are attempting to stop the invasion but is also trying to silence any surviving 'witnesses' of the Black Mesa incident.

[h1]LEGACY OF HALF-LIFE (PROS):[/h1]
+ First FPS game to fully incorporate a Narrative-Driven story (as opposed to the industry standard of maze gallery shooters which was the Wolfenstein 3D / Doom mechanic)
+ Excellent level designs
+ Realistic combat mechanics (may be not as realistic now in 2015, but 17 years ago it was)
+ Fun puzzles
+ Great sound effects
+ First FPS game to incorporate scripted sequences for its level transitions rather than cut-scenes
+ Relatively advanced AI (back in 1998), with enemies actively dodging, tactically retreating and often times baiting you into an ambush.
+ Fun fast-paced multiplayer action that set the foundations for Counter-Strike which started as a mere mod of Half-Life
+ Mods; although Half-Life is not the first video game to be modded, it is the first to have several such mods become their own full games that still retain their Half-Life heritage
+ Challenging difficulty modes (but this is a given since most old-school shooters were challenging)

[h1]OLD GAME MECHANICS THAT NEW GENERATION OF GAMERS MAY NOT LIKE (CONS):[/h1]
- Perpetual sprint with optional walking by pressing “Shift” (as opposed to today's standard which is the reverse)
- No objective tracker (players may forget what they were doing especially if they haven't played in a while)
- Melee weapon needs to be equipped rather than bound to a hotkey (though CS:GO players won't have a problem with this)

[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]
[b][u]MASTERPIECE[/u][/b] is the only word that best describes Half-Life in my opinion.  Although some of its mechanics may not necessarily be applicable in today's (2015) standard, the same can still be considered as part of its charm, much like how most of us still enjoy watching old-school movies and TV shows.

[h1]WORTH IT?:[/h1]
[b]MUST BUY AND MUST HAVE[/b]. I, however, do recommend you purchase the Half-Life Anthology if you already have Half-Life 2 but if you don't have it, get Half-Life Complete.

[h1]ADDITIONAL INFO (Not necessary for the review):[/h1]
The advent of Half-Life was a turning point in gaming history, most notably, the First-person shooter genre.  Before this game, the only FPS standard to be followed was Wolfenstein 3D, Doom and Quake, with the first two being plotless maze shooters and Quake being the first to implement a backstory but still retained the maze-like levels. With Half-Life, developers saw a potential for FPS games to combine intense action and gunplay with effective narrative story-telling through leniar levels (which is heavily abused by some FPS games today) and realistic game mechanics (a title, which most people agree, was held by the Metal Gear Solid franchise, a third-person action game)

Let’s put this in an analogy: Wolfenstein 3D is the Wheel (basically invented the mainstream FPS genre), Doom is the Horse-Drawn Carriage (Doom made FPS games extremely popular, accessible and widespread), Quake is the Steam Engine (Quake bridge the gap between plotless maze shooters and  plot driven FPS games [i]Credit: Steam User RGX12 for pointing this out[/i]) and Half-Life is the Ford Model T Car (Half-Life set the standard for modern day FPS games who's basic and essential features still survives today.)

Every PC gamer on the face of the Earth will have heard about Half-Life, Valve’s first product, due to its immense popularity ever since its release in November 1998. Half-Life really is one of those games you have to play before you die. I unfortunately missed out on this classic as a child due to being predominantly a console gamer but have finally gotten around to playing it via Steam and I must say it was a pleasant and enjoyable game to play.

The player steps in the shoes of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist employed at the secret underground teleportation research facility Black Mesa. In the due course of the teams’ research, experimentations and developments, something goes disastrously wrong and creates something called the Resonance Cascade which starts to flood the human world with alien-like creatures from a parallel dimension.

The game runs on the legacy Goldsrc engine and the gameplay reminded me of the styles I’ve observed in the original Thief games which used a completely different engine (Dark Engine). Initially, my impressions of the controls were that Gordon Freeman moved too fast, but I adapted to the game’s controls and this quickly subsided. The gameplay is a simple, intuitive and generic first person shooter (not generic in terms of Call of Duty) that plays out in a linear fashion. The linear world is by no means a negative aspect of the game because this game is best presented in a linear style due to its story. There are no inter-gameplay cutscenes and the player views the world uninterrupted through the eyes of Gordon Freeman. A arsenal of weapons are at your disposal to combat the feral Marine soldiers and alien creatures in any manner you feel comfortable. The signature crowbar is something best remembered from the series. The game provides a decent challenged on medium difficulty, but doesn’t provide an excruciating experience of pulling your hair out whilst shouting obscene things at your monitor with an evil frown.

With this game’s age in mind, one aspect of its design is its character models. Whilst, decent a lot of them are recycled and lack in variety. I remember about three typical Black Mesa scientists (an Einstein looking man, a black man, and a middle-aged white man). On the other hand, there is variety in the enemies which are conceptually intriguing ranging from leaping headcrabs similar to the creatures in the Alien films, ceiling dwelling Barnacles that suck you up with their tongues, as well as about a dozen more.

In a nutshell if you fancy having a blast from the past and either experiencing a classic for the first time or revisiting it, then grab a crowbar and get smashing headcrabs. That is, grab the crowbar in the game... not in real life.

It was back at the end of the 90's when this game came out and changed my life forever. I was a little kid and my father used to play it while I was watching him, and I got caught by its great plot, its gameplay and its setting. I played this game over and over like more than a hundred times and it still takes me out of breath. Live the life of Gordon Freeman, take a look at how a normal day at work can be the beginning of the longest and the most intense journey of all times. And live it all throug the eyes of the mute orange-suited redhead hero who can solve any probem with his crowbar. No cut-scenes, no scripted sequences, not a single look at what Gordon Freeman himself could not see. You'll not be aware of what is really going on until the real end. Emotional, breathtaking, this is one of the game you must have. At its time, Half-Life totally changed the way videogames were seen, and even if nowadays actual games are based on the concept that Half-Life brought to the world of videogames, you will still see that this game has something unique, that will still take your breath away.

This game has also got a wonderful multiplayer deathmatch mode that even if it hasn't got many players as it used to have, it's still one of the funniest experiences you will have on a multiplayer game. Try it if you don't believe me.

If you're a gamer and have never heard the name Half-Life, I'm sorry to say that you're either overly sheltered, willfully ignorant or just too young. For those of us who enjoy First-Person Shooter [FPS] games, Half-Life was just as influential to the genre as Doom or Quake (for those of you who have never heard of these titles, Wikipedia is your friend). Classics such as Halo: Combat Evolved and newer titles such as Bioshock: Infinite have been influenced by this game, and older games such as Counter-Strike were mods of Half-Life. In short, the entire FPS genre has been creatively influenced by the atmosphere and style of Half-Life.                          - FYI: Final Score is at the end -

- The Look - 

Half-Life was released by Valve (the parent company of Steam) in 1998 for the PC. As such, the graphics are abysmal by modern standards. If you are a nostalgic gamer such as myself, though, the low graphics can be humorous and even add to the charm of the game at times. There are numerous texture packs available if you cannot handle such old graphics.

- The Story (Mild Spoiler Alert) - 

You're a government agent/scientist who gets involved with some experiments on unknown substances. Through testing these substances, you somehow open a portal and unleash an alien horde into the testing facility. You must then find and fight your way out of the facility. Pretty simple and straightforward-sounding. Half-Life was the first-ever game to tell its story completely through scripted sequences (events triggered by certain programmable requirements) and as such has no cutscenes. This is a very nice element to the game as you retain control of your character throughout the entire game.

- The Sounds - 

For some reason, Valve decided they needed to make everything sound like it was coming from the inside of an echo chamber. There is a lot of reverb on just about every noise if you are not completely outdoors. Again, this is an element where modern technology has progressed as to make this appear foolish and unappealing. Give it some time before you make any judgments, though. The effect enhances the scariness of some situations, in my opinion. If you ever play any of the other Valve games (Portal, Team Fortress 2, Portal 2, etc.), you will discover that a LOT of sounds and music in those games originated from Half-Life.

- The Movement - 

You run. You run a lot. You run really fast. You have the option to walk and the option to sneak, but 98% of the time you will be running. Sometimes, especially for unfamiliar novices to the game, the speed is too much and you end up running into an alien patrol before you realize that you just passed through that hallway. You will eventually get used to it, though. Half-Life was one of the first games (if not the first; I'm not sure) to implement the "jump-crouch" concept. If you jump and hold the crouch button, you can actually jump onto higher platforms. Instead of lowering your body, jump-crouching raises your legs and feet, giving you more clearance to vault onto objects.

- The Combat - 

If an enemy sees you, they will throw a grenade. Expect to be spammed if you are spotted. Half-Life is a quick-save/quick-load supportive game; you can choose to disregard this if you want a "purist" experience. Enemies in this game are rather easy to defeat in the beginning and get harder as the game progresses, but each new type presents its own unique traits that make it hard to kill. The weapon switching system is confusing to a modern gamer at first; it requires you to scroll (or press hot-key) and then left-click to actually arm that weapon. The left shift button, by default, switches instantaneously back to the previous weapon used, allowing for a much faster switch. Weapons and ammo are decently plentiful if you are conservative enough.

- The Mods and The Legacy - 

Half-Life is the number one most modded game of all time. There are more mods available for this game than any other, followed by Morrowind and Quake. The mods have spawned entire new game series, as in the case of Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Half-Life also holds the trophy for another gaming phenomenon: most-played for speedruns. If you are unfamiliar with a speedrun, the gist is that you attempt to start and finish the game as fast as possible.

- The Downsides - 

Half-Life is an ancient piece of software by today's standards. With the advent of 2015, this game is now 17 years old (nearly old enough to purchase cigarettes!). Its age shows in many things. Several furniture items are completely cubic or square and have no roundness. Cockroaches are diamond-shaped. There are only three different models used for the human enemies and three for the friendly scientists. Each alien type has only one model/skin. The NPCs and enemies can get very repetitive at times, as such. Other than this, there aren't very many bad points to Half-Life. Its continued success and popularity speak for its quality and innovation.

- The Conclusion - 

Half-Life is a classic in many gamers' opinions. I am of the same mindset. I completely recommend this game, despite its age and shortcomings, as a fun experience that will provide a decent challenge.

Final Score: 10/10
